There are virtually countless reasons why your Internet might not be performing as you expect it to, but a few common reasons include the following:  Old software or hardware Too many other computers or mobile items on the network Ongoing downloads Signal interference from walls or other appliances Low Internet speed from your Internet Service Provider . Many Internet Service Providers advertise speeds of "up to" a certain number, meaning that the top speed itself isn't guaranteed. Most of the time, your computer's highest upload or download speed will be a little bit lower than the advertised speed. If the actual speed is close to the advertised speed, your ISP isn't the problem. Check your service plan to see what speed you are paying for, then compare that number with the actual speed that you found. If the speeds aren't anywhere close to each other, you'll need to call your ISP.  If you haven't upgraded your internet in a long time, you may be able to find faster internet for lower prices. Check all of the providers in your area. Don't fall for the megabit/megabyte trap. ISPs advertise in megabits, not megabytes. There are 8 megabits (Mb) in a megabyte (MB), so if you are paying for 25 megabits per second (Mbps), then that's just over 3 megabytes per second (MBps) of actual transfer speed. If you are connected to the internet via a Wi-Fi router, you'll find that your Internet speed drops as you move further away from your router. Stay as close as possible to your router for maximum Internet speed. Make sure that your router and your computer have plenty of room all the way around to prevent overheating. If your router's signal has to travel through even one wall or appliance (e.g., a refrigerator), its signal will be weakened. A good rule of thumb is to have your router visible from where you're using your computer or mobile at all times. If your router is on a different floor than you, you may not even be able to receive a signal. Like a freeway, your Wi-Fi network can only handle a certain amount of traffic before it slows down. If possible, make sure that your computer is the only connection to your router; this will give you the best Internet results. It isn't always feasible to limit Internet access to one computer, but you can turn off and unplug things like smart TVs, extra computers, video game consoles, and anything else that maintains an Internet connection even when turned off, instead of relying on Wi-Fi. Most computers can plug directly into the back of the router using an Ethernet cable, which removes the lag time between the router's signal departing and your computer receiving the signal.  If you use a Mac computer, you'll most likely need an Ethernet to USB-C adapter if you want to plug your computer into the router. You cannot connect mobile platforms (e.g., smartphones and tablets) to Ethernet.

Initial acceptance is a difficult but ultimately liberating stage where you are 'going along' with the break-up because you have no choice, and you are starting to see that the two of you just aren't meant to be, finally stopping trying to resolve things, and it's essential to acknowledge and accept this reality in order to begin the healing process. Redirected Hope is a stage where you start to assess the possibility that you may be okay on the other side of the break-up, and you begin to feel some level of hope that your future--whatever it includes--will be brighter, often due to the fact that you're starting to see the possibilities and opportunities that lie ahead, and you're beginning to feel a renewed sense of purpose and possibility. When a relationship ends, you often feel resigned to just get by in life, lying around in sorrow, eating junk food, or rewatching your favorite TV shows or movies, but yes, you have to grieve, but recognize that the wallowing isn't a requirement, as it's essential to acknowledge and process your emotions in a healthy and constructive way, allowing you to move forward and start anew. Here is the revised text:

After being dumped, you may find yourself wanting the person even more. This intense yearning can make you do things you never thought you'd do. You might beg your boyfriend not to leave, resorting to a variety of embarrassing tactics to prevent him from going through with the break-up. Research suggests that emotional pain can often resemble physical pain, making your heartache feel all-consuming. You'll do virtually anything to make it stop, which is why it's essential to set some boundaries to prevent any dramatic actions on your behalf.

To avoid further emotional distress, it's crucial to avoid your boyfriend at all costs until you have fully come to terms with being dumped. Refrain from showing up at his doorstep and questioning his motives, as this can lead to more conflict and prolong the healing process. If you must, delete his contact information from your phone and computer to help you move on. The simple action of pressing "delete" can bring you closure, and the shock of scrolling through your contacts and not seeing him listed may be just what you need to remind you that it's time to let go.

When someone breaks your heart, and you don't see it coming, you are bound to experience a range of emotions. You may have a strong desire to push these emotions away, telling yourself "He's not worth my tears." However, having loved someone means you should, at least, allow yourself to properly grieve the relationship. This process can be challenging, but it's essential for healing and moving forward.

There are seven stages you can expect to go through while grieving:

1. **Questioning**: You are consumed by a desire to understand what happened or what went wrong. You may try to seek out your ex, argue with friends and relatives, or even consult strangers to find clarity about what happened.

2. **Denial**: You have trouble accepting that your relationship has truly ended. You may continue to hope that your love together can be saved or refuse to believe otherwise.

3. **Bargaining**: You offer up any and every solution just as long as you two can stay together. You promise to change, become the perfect girlfriend, or take responsibility for the entire relationship.

4. **Relapse**: You manage to convince your ex to give the relationship another shot, only to go through the same break-up process all over again. Eventually, you are finally convinced that it cannot be saved.

5. **Anger**: This stage occurs when you have released some of your fears about being single and can now recognize that you deserved better than what you got. Your anger may be directed at yourself, your ex, or the circumstances.

6. **Initial acceptance**: At this point, you are "going along" with the break-up because you have no choice. You are starting to see that the two of you just aren't meant to be, and you finally stop trying to resolve things.

7. **Redirected Hope**: As you come to accept the circumstances, you start to assess the possibility that you may be okay on the other side of the break-up. You begin to feel some level of hope that your future – whatever it includes – will be brighter.

When a relationship ends, you often feel resigned to just getting by in life. You may lie around in sorrow, eat junk food, rewatch your favorite TV shows or movies, or engage in other comfort-seeking behaviors. While it's okay to grieve, recognize that wallowing isn't a requirement. Set a precise deadline for yourself – it can be a week, two weeks, or a month (depending on the seriousness or length of the relationship) – and tell yourself that after that, you will no longer sit around wasting your days in misery. Make an active choice to lead a meaningful life, alone for now.

As you try to successfully grieve your relationship, it's a good idea to temporarily purge your life of any reminders of your doomed relationship. Holding on to personal items can demonstrate that you expect your ex to come back someday. Toss these items, such as pictures, gifts, love notes, and the like, in a box to tuck away in storage or in an attic. Later, when you have fully grieved and come to terms with the loss of the relationship, you can decide what to do with these items.

To create an avocado hair mask, start by cutting an avocado in half using a sharp knife and carefully removing the pit. Next, in a clean bowl, mash 1/2 of the avocado with a fork until no chunks remain. Alternatively, you can spoon the avocado into a blender or food processor and blend for a few seconds until smooth. It's essential to use a ripe avocado so that you can easily break down any chunks and mash or blend until smooth. If your hair is very thick and/or long, you might need to use the whole avocado. If you only use half, you can store the avocado half for future use.

To enhance the benefits of the avocado, you can add various nutrients to the mixture. Some options include:

- 1 egg, which contains vitamins A and E, as well as biotin, to promote healthy growth
- 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of plain yogurt, which helps strengthen your hair and make it extra shiny
- 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of olive oil, which is highly conditioning and can help prevent breakage and promote hair growth
- A few drops of your favorite essential oil, such as peppermint or lavender, which can help mask unpleasant smells and add extra nutrients

You can mix all of these add-ins together or choose one or a few depending on your hair type and desired effect. Use a fork to stir, or add to your blender or food processor until your add-in is completely mixed with the mashed avocado. If you are using the whole avocado instead of just half, double the add-ins.

For example, for a whole avocado worth of paste, you will need 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of plain yogurt. Once you have mixed your add-ins with the mashed avocado, scoop up a dollop of the avocado paste and massage it into a section of your hair for about 1 minute. Repeat this process until all of your hair is covered and you have used all of the paste.

If you have really thick and/or long hair, you may need to make a bit more of the paste at this point to cover all of your hair. It's a good idea to wear clothes that you don't mind staining, or you can wrap a towel around your shoulders to protect your clothing. This will give your hair ample time to absorb the nutrients from the avocado paste. You can leave your hair uncovered, or you can protect your clothes and surroundings by putting on a shower cap, or by lightly wrapping your hair in a towel.

After you have let the avocado paste sit in your hair for 15 minutes, wash it out thoroughly with water. Once the mixture is rinsed out of your hair, dry and style your hair as usual. Your hair should feel extra soft and smooth. Avocado paste alone should not make your hair greasy or weighed down, so you shouldn't need to use shampoo to get it all out. If you use olive oil or an egg as add-ins, however, you may need to use your regular shampoo to get all of the treatment out.

For best results, condition your hair with an avocado paste once every 2 weeks. This will keep your hair moisturized and shiny without weighing it down. Feel free to experiment with different add-ins every 2 weeks until you find what works best for your hair.

Do not breed unless you have plans that include the proper long-term commitment to the breed, the health and safety of the bitch and puppies, and the willingness to completely understand the bulldog and its needs. There are too many backyard breeders trying to jump in and breed dogs with almost no experience or understanding of this unique breed. They see the prices they sell for and try to get in and fill their pockets with money, blinded by profit rather than the well-being of the bulldogs. The sad part about this is the end result is not good for the bulldog. Many bulldogs suffer from breathing difficulties because of a combination of flat faces, large tongues, and small windpipes. If either of the mating pair of bulldogs has had to have surgery in order to open up their nostrils, trim back parts of their soft palates, or remove their tonsils, do not breed them. The genetics for a crowded throat will be passed onto the pups and will perpetuate these distressing problems. Even if your bulldogs haven't required surgery, you should still avoid breeding them if they struggle to breathe. Do not breed the female during summer months if she has breathing troubles. The hot weather will compound the issue during pregnancy and cause the bitch undue distress. Evidence suggests that the character of the mother is passed onto her puppies. If she is excessively nervous or aggressive, her puppies are likely to have similar non-ideal behavior patterns. The best bitch to breed from is a calm, friendly, and gentle dog. A calmer female will also make a better mother who is less likely to be snappy or insecure when it comes to her puppies. It is vital to ensure that she has healthy skin and is free from skin parasites. A form of mange caused by the demodex mite can be made much worse by the stress of pregnancy, and she could lose her fur and develop a rhino-like skin. In addition, the demodex mite can be transferred to the pups at whelping, which means they are born with the mite and will go on to have poor coats and skin. Not only is this undesirable but it can make the pups harder to sell, so you are more likely to be left with them on your hands. One full month before you want to breed your English bulldogs, you should have your veterinarian perform a full physical examination of the female. Ensure that she is up to date on all vaccinations, that she's free of any worms, and that she does not test positive for brucellosis, a bacterial disease that can cause spontaneous abortion. 4. Double-click the downloaded tool to install it on your flash drive.
5. Place the installation CD in the disk drive, or insert the USB flash drive into one of the computer's USB ports.

To boot from the installation medium, follow these steps:

1. Click the "Start" button (represented by a Windows icon) and then click the "Power" button (represented by a circle with a line through it).

Common keys include the function keys (e.g., F2), the Esc key, and the Del key. If you're not sure which key to press or hold, consult your computer's BIOS documentation by searching for your computer's model, the word "bios," and the word "key."

Once you've entered the BIOS, follow these steps:

1. Open the Boot or Advanced tab.
2. Use the arrow keys to select your CD drive or USB drive.
3. Press the "+" key to move the drive up to the top of the list.
4. Press the "Save and Exit" key as specified by your BIOS legend, then confirm by pressing another key if prompted.

Your computer will resume rebooting, and you should see the installation menu appear. To access the Command Prompt, press the "Shift+F10" keys.

In the Command Prompt, follow these steps to add a new administrator account:

1. Type "move c:\windows\system32\utilman.exe c:\windows\system32\utilman.exe.bak" and press "Enter."
2. Type "copy c:\windows\system32\cmd.exe c:\windows\system32\utilman.exe" and press "Enter."
3. Type "wpeutil reboot" and press "Enter." Then, remove your installation media from the computer. This will ensure that Windows reboots to the login screen rather than back into the installation setup.

But now, those memories were all I had left, and they only served to remind me of what I had lost. As we arrived at the church and saw my family gathered, it was hard to hold back tears. The atmosphere was heavy with grief, and I couldn't help but feel a sense of sadness wash over me. Seeing my aunt, who had been so strong and brave, was perhaps the hardest part of the day. I knew that she would get through this, but it was the thought of her pain that really got to me. My uncle, an ordained pastor, played a crucial role in the service, and his words of comfort helped ease some of the pain. After the service, we all gathered at the cemetery, standing on a hill in the shade, near my cousin's final resting place. We then met at a local restaurant for a late lunch and some drinks, and it was good to see my family, but it was also bittersweet. But even in the midst of all this pain, I knew that my family is strong and stronger together, and I was confident that we would get through this, just as we had with any other tragedy that had come our way. It was a difficult day, but I knew that we would emerge from it even more united and resilient. I took comfort in the thought that we would get through this together, and that thought allowed me to hold on to some hope.

- Are you willing and able to take on the responsibility of pet care?

**Types of Pets and Their Maintenance**

- Low maintenance pets (fish, snakes, lizards, turtles, cats, rabbits, canaries, parakeets, guinea pigs, gerbils, hamsters, mice, and rats): 15-30 minutes daily maintenance, weekly cage and litter box cleaning.
- Medium maintenance pets (dogs): 1-2 hours daily care, including walking.
- High maintenance pets (horses, parrots, pot belly pigs): require a lot of time and space.

**Questions to Consider Before Getting a Pet**

- How will your pet get along with other people?
- How will your pet behave?
- How much will it cost to take care of your pet?
- How long will your pet live?
- What type of food and accommodations will your pet need?
- Who will take care of your pet when you're away?

**Preparing for Pet Ownership**

- Learn as much as you can about the animal you're interested in.
- Figure out the supplies you'll need.
- Talk to friends who have pets for advice.
- Read books, magazines, and the internet for more information.
- Watch television shows or videos about the animal.
- Take notes and use them to impress your parents.

**Important Considerations**

- Consider your family's lifestyle and schedule.
- Think about the space you have in your home for a pet.
- Check if anyone in your household is allergic to the pet you're interested in.
- Ask yourself why you want a pet and what type of pet is right for you.

llama3.polished_text:
Here's the refined text:

A contract is a legally binding agreement between two or more parties that stipulates the terms of the agreement. Modern organizations maintain a large inventory of contracts and other legal documents. A typical large Fortune organization manages up to 40,000 active contracts at any given time (Pery and Simon, 2019). Substantial time and cost are involved in manually reviewing and analyzing these contracts for due diligence and risk analysis. According to a study (Dodd, 2018), more than 50% of contract review tasks, such as clause identification and classification (Zhao, 2019), are repetitive in nature and require legal domain knowledge and understanding. Due to the extremely large scale and ever-increasing volume of contracts, manually segregating paragraphs in these contracts to derive actionable information is a monumental task for law firms or legal departments. Automatic categorization and classification of legal clauses and provisions using natural language processing and artificial intelligence have become a topic of great academic and commercial interest (Katz et al., 2023; DALE, 2019).

The primary research interest of this paper is the classification of provisions found in contracts into topics. Two important considerations are involved: A) Sophisticated neural network classification methods require a large set of labeled, curated data, which can be difficult and costly to obtain; B) Classifier models trained on general language corpora are not efficient for the legal classification task, as legal texts have a specialized language and distinctive vocabulary with peculiar expressions and terms that do not commonly occur in day-to-day spoken or written language.

This research focuses on the use of transfer learning (Zhuang et al., 2019) techniques, which look promising in addressing the two challenges above. The central tenet of these techniques is to first train a general-purpose language model to serve as a base model by training on a very large general corpus without using any task-specific labeled dataset. This base model encodes only the semantic information as lower-order features. Then, this foundational model is fine-tuned (Dodge et al., 2020) and customized for the classification task using relatively fewer labeled data points and the weights learned in the base model. By following this approach, higher-order feature representations are fine-tuned, making them more efficient at the specific task by utilizing the lower-order general features learned in the original base model without having to re-create them.

The aim of this research is to examine the applicability of fine-tuning a pre-trained large language model for a legal domain classification task. In support of this, the main topic of a provision in a contract will be predicted. The corpus of contracts used is obtained from public domain filings in the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) curated in Legal General Language Understanding Evaluation (LexGLUE) (Chalkidis et al., 2021), which uses the LEDGAR dataset (Tuggener et al., 2020). Each label in the dataset represents the single most important topic (subject) in the corresponding contract provision (refer to Table 1 for the sample data format). The provisions and their count are provided in Appendix Table A.

- Broken long sentences into shorter ones for clarity and readability.
- Corrected punctuation and grammar errors.
- Used commas and semicolons to improve sentence structure.
- Removed unnecessary words and phrases to enhance concision.
- Added reference citations in the correct format.
- Standardized the citation style to a consistent format.
- Reformatted the text for improved readability.

**Effective Bill Payment Strategies for a Stress-Free Financial Life**

To maintain a healthy financial standing, it's essential to establish a consistent bill payment routine. Whether you receive a monthly or bi-monthly paycheck, setting aside dedicated time to pay your bills can help prevent late payments and associated penalties.

**Choose a System that Works for You**

Consider the following:

1.  If you get paid monthly, you might pay bills once a month, on the same day each month.
2.  If you get paid twice a month, you may have two days a month that you pay bills, such as the 15th and 30th.
3.  Whichever system you choose, ensure you stick to it.

**Create a Reminders and Calendars**

To avoid missing payment deadlines, mark your calendar or set reminders on your phone. This way, you'll never forget to pay your bills on time.

**Adjust for Holidays and Vacations**

Keep in mind that you may need to adjust your payment day for holidays or vacation times. Make sure you have a plan in place to avoid any disruptions to your bill payment routine.

**Track Your Bills and Payments**

At the beginning of each month, create a checklist of the bills you're expecting. This can be a handwritten or electronic list, depending on your preference. You should have a section on the list to mark if the bill was received and when the bill was paid.

**Monitor Your Bills and Adjust as Necessary**

If you're expecting a bill but don't receive it, check with the company to see if there was an error. You don't want to pay a bill late because you weren't on top of things.

**Automated Bill Payment Options**

Automated bill pay is beneficial for expenses that don't change every month, such as:

1.  Phone bills
2.  Student loans
3.  Rent
4.  Mortgages

When setting up automated payments, make sure to note the dates the money will be deducted from your account to ensure there's enough money to cover the payment.

**Limitations of Automated Bill Pay**

While automated bill pay is convenient, it's not suitable for bills that may change every month, like credit card bills. This is because the amount due may be higher than expected, which can throw off your budget if you're not careful.

**Additional Considerations**

Some companies charge for automatic bill pay. Make sure it's a free service before signing up.

**Benefits of Online Bill Payment**

Paying bills online offers numerous benefits, including:

1.  Convenience: You can pay bills from anywhere with an internet connection.
2.  Time-saving: You won't need to buy envelopes, stamps, or checks.
3.  Immediate access to account information: You can view your account balances, payment history, and due dates online.
4.  Faster processing: Online payments are typically processed faster than checks.

**Online Account Setup**

To take advantage of online bill payment, set up an online account for each of your bills. You can link your bank account to the online account, so you don't need to enter your payment information each month.

**Other Helpful Resources**

1.  Notifications: Sign up for notifications about upcoming bills to stay on top of your payments.
2.  Online account access: Use your online account to track your payments, view your account balances, and check your payment history.
3.  Budgeting tools: Many online accounts offer budgeting tools and payment reminders to help you stay on track.

**Manual Payment Considerations**

If you prefer to send checks by mail, make sure the check arrives by the due date or is post-dated before the due date. If possible, pay your bill as soon as it arrives to avoid forgetting about it or mailing it in too late.

**Stock Up on Bill-Paying Supplies**

Keep a steady supply of:

1.  Envelopes
2.  Stamps
3.  Checks

This way, you'll never be caught off guard when it's time to pay your bills.

However, previous studies on gender bias in LLMs usually focus on certain tasks in the English context and use single-dimensional evaluation methods, such as those employed by Wan et al. (2023), who assessed the bias of LLM responses in a limited domain, and Kotek et al. Moreover, different languages may have different degrees of gender bias in LLM generations, ranging from subtle, such as the bias in pronoun usage, to severe, such as the bias in stereotypes and stereotypes-based responses, which can be influenced by various factors, including the language of instruction, the cultural background of the users, and the design of the LLMs themselves. To achieve this, we present three quantitative evaluation measurements for gender bias in LLMs, which can reveal three-dimensional aspects of gender bias, including linguistic features, such as word choice and sentence structure, social context, such as user demographics and cultural norms, and cognitive dimensions, such as user expectations and bias perception, by analyzing the language patterns, sentiment, and intent of the LLM-generated text. Based on these measurements, we conduct experiments in six different languages using a range of state-of-the-art LLMs, including GPT-3/4 (Brown et al., 2020), enabling us to compare the levels and nuances of gender bias across these languages and identify patterns and trends in LLM-generated text, such as the use of gender-neutral language in Swedish and the perpetuation of stereotypes in Arabic. Our approaches facilitate comprehensive analyses of both lexicon and sentiment aspects of gender bias across different languages, providing insights into how diverse instructions, such as user intent and cultural background, may influence gender biases in LLM generations in different ways, and highlighting the importance of considering language and cultural context when addressing bias in AI systems, which can lead to more accurate and effective language models that are responsive to the needs of diverse users. The main findings of our study can be categorized into several key conclusions, including the need for more nuanced evaluation methods, such as the ones we present in this study, the importance of considering language and cultural context, and the potential for LLMs to perpetuate existing social biases, as shown by our experiments with GPT-3/4 (Brown et al., 2020), which we present in detail in the following sections, including the development of personalized language models that can adapt to the needs of diverse users and the creation of language-based interventions that can mitigate social biases in language use.

llama3.polished_text:
With the rapid development of large language models (LLMs) and their widespread applications in various domains, these models have evolved beyond their role as mere tools for daily convenience. Notably, LLMs have been increasingly prevalent in dialogue systems (Bae et al., 2022) and creative writings (Swanson et al., 2021), demonstrating their capabilities in generating human-like content. Furthermore, their influence extends to social domains such as education (Kasneci et al., 2023; AlAfnan et al., 2023) and the technology industry (Dong et al., 2023), where they play a significant role in shaping social attitudes and norms.

However, the existence of bias in LLMs is a pressing concern, as their social influence can exacerbate underlying legal and ethical implications (Weidinger et al., 2021; Deshpande et al., 2023). In particular, the issue of gender bias in LLMs has been a subject of interest in the field of natural language processing (NLP). Previous studies have identified gender bias in various NLP models (Gupta et al., 2022; Sheng et al., 2019), highlighting the need for more comprehensive evaluation methods.

Most existing works on gender bias in LLMs focus on specific tasks within the English context and employ single-dimensional evaluation methods (Wan et al., 2023; Kotek et al., 2023). However, this approach neglects the fact that LLMs are often instructed differently in various contexts, resulting in diverse manifestations of gender bias. Considering the vast linguistic and cultural diversity of LLM users and the strong multilingual capabilities of LLMs themselves (Lai et al., 2023; Bang et al., 2023; Rathje et al., 2023; Shi et al., 2023), it is essential to emphasize the various language features and cultural influences that impact the occurrence of gender bias in different languages.

Different languages may exhibit varying degrees of gender bias in LLM generations, underscoring the need for a nuanced understanding of these biases. Acknowledging and mitigating these biases is crucial for ensuring that LLMs are more equitable and culturally aware in their applications. To address the limitations of existing evaluation methods, our study focuses on the conversations undertaken by LLMs and explores gender bias in multiple dimensions.

We present three quantitative evaluation measurements for gender bias in LLMs, which can reveal three-dimensional aspects of gender bias. These measurements are designed to facilitate a comprehensive analysis of both lexicon and sentiment aspects of gender bias across different languages. We conduct experiments using a range of state-of-the-art LLMs, including GPT-3/4 (Brown et al., 2020), in six different languages, allowing us to compare the levels and nuances of gender bias across these languages.

Our approaches provide insights into the impact of diverse instructions on gender biases in LLM generations and highlight the need for culturally aware and linguistically sensitive evaluation methods. The main results of our exploration can be categorized into the following conclusions:

1.  The proposed evaluation measurements are effective in revealing three-dimensional aspects of gender bias in LLMs.
2.  The levels and nuances of gender bias vary significantly across different languages.
3.  Diverse instructions can influence gender biases in LLM generations in distinct ways, underscoring the need for culturally aware and linguistically sensitive evaluation methods.
4.  Our findings provide valuable insights for developers and researchers working on LLMs, emphasizing the importance of addressing gender bias in these models.

By highlighting the complexities of gender bias in LLMs and presenting a comprehensive evaluation framework, our study contributes to the development of more equitable and culturally aware LLMs that can benefit a wide range of applications.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Two months ago, serious safety issues began to emerge, forcing me to leave the environment. Despite recurring safety issues, our supervisor simply kept piling on more work. Her boss told her it wasn't important and they could skip doing it, but my supervisor wanted to impress everyone and be "number 1," so she ignored her boss's advice and pursued her own goals. Whispers began behind her back, and the other pharmacists started to worry about their licenses as the pressure mounted on them. I found the wrong pills in a bottle on the shelf, and my supervisor got angry, even though I wasn't responsible for filling that bottle that week. Nothing was ever mentioned again, and I would lie awake at 3 in the morning wondering if the wrong medication had gone out unnoticed. This income was crucial to my family, but the job was toxic to my self-worth, and I knew I'd be liable if anything happened, regardless of who was truly at fault. My job had been toxic from the start; my supervisor was abusive and infamous in our company for being difficult to work with. My coworkers trained me by yelling at me and then arguing and ranting with each other in Spanish about me, creating a hostile work environment. But I persisted; I didn't want to let them win. Every morning I hoped I would get in a car wreck serious enough that I couldn't work for the foreseeable future. I snapped at my husband and my child. Every moment not spent at work was filled with crushing dread that I'd have to go back in a few hours. My marriage suffered greatly, and my self-esteem was severely damaged. Yet still I kept on. But that one little tablet of Tramadol was enough to snap me out of it. I was terrified that someone with over a decade of experience had mistakenly put a controlled substance into a bottle of blood pressure medication. And no one caught it. The daily counts of the controlled medication didn't seem off at first, but that seemed odd to me. Every tablet of those is so tightly accounted for that someone either counted wrong or noticed but didn't have the time to deal with the paperwork. How many times had it happened before? Why was I being blamed? These questions ate at me, and they ate at me until I realized I was killing myself for a job that would throw me under the bus, even knowing that criminal charges could be brought against me when I didn't do anything wrong. So I quit, and now we are relying on food banks and credit to make do.

It's impossible to predict when you might be contacted about a potential match—it could be in a few months, a few years, or never at all. Regardless of the timeline, it's essential to keep your registry contact information up-to-date so you can move forward with the process as soon as possible if you are matched with a patient. To determine if you're a match, a doctor will compare the proteins in your cells with those of the patient. The more similar they are, the higher the chance of the patient's body accepting the transplant. When contacted as a potential match for a patient, respond promptly as instructed.

The donation is voluntary, so just because you're matched doesn't mean you have to proceed. Take the time to carefully consider this decision. While backing out may have a serious impact on the patient's health, you may have legitimate reasons for doing so, such as a health issue or being unable to take time off to recover. If you decide to donate, you'll sign a consent form. No doctors or registry officials will pressure you to sign this form—it's your own decision.

If you decide not to donate, inform the registry and doctors right away, so they can begin searching for another donor. After being matched, you'll undergo a physical examination and possibly more tests, including another cheek swab or cell sample. If you're chosen as the best match for the patient, you'll attend an information session, where you'll learn more about the donation process, potential risks, and side effects. You'll also sign the consent form at this session.

At the information session, you'll also learn whether you'll undergo a bone marrow or peripheral blood stem cell (PBSC) donation. You can ask the doctors about the patient, and while most information is confidential, centers can typically share the patient's age, gender, and disease.

If you choose a traditional bone marrow donation, you'll be in a hospital outpatient facility for the day and possibly overnight. You'll undergo general anesthesia for about 2 hours. During the donation, you'll be lying on your stomach, and the doctors will use hollow needles to withdraw liquid cells from small incisions in your pelvic bone. General anesthesia is used in about 96% of bone marrow donations, but some facilities use regional anesthesia, either spinal or epidural. The procedure removes only a small fraction of your total cells, and your body will naturally replenish itself within a few weeks of the donation.

Before a PBSC donation, you'll be injected with filgrastim, a medicine that increases the amount of stem cells in your blood. You'll receive these injections over the 5 days leading up to the donation. During the donation, a needle will be inserted into each of your arms, and blood will be drawn from one arm, then passed through a blood cell separator machine to collect the necessary cells. The remaining blood will be returned to your body through your other arm. The cells removed by the blood separator machine are blood-forming cells, platelets, and some white blood cells, while plasma and red blood cells go back into your body.

Your first filgrastim injections will be given at a donor center or clinic. On days 2-4, you can receive your injections at your home or workplace. You'll receive the last injection at the center, followed by the donation itself, which can take up to 8 hours.

They took B&G to the mall and to the theme park, and it was great to see them experience new things together as a family. It was a warm, still summer evening, and we went out back after supper to sit on the porch. Apparently there aren't fireflies where they live now, so they were excited to experience this childhood wonder. I found four bottles – some glass, some plastic – and watched in bemusement as all four girls ran around collecting fireflies in their bottles. In some climates, like Miami, a cigar can be left in its wrapper for a short period of time without concern for freshness, due to the already high humidity levels. People living in dry climates, such as Arizona or Alaska, may need to store the cigar for more than 24 hours to address the dryness. The tobacco in good cigars is grown in a tropical climate with humidity levels typically between 65 and 72 percent, which helps maintain the tobacco's natural moisture. Cigars are made from whole, wrapped sheets of tobacco, which need to stay oily and moist for optimal construction, as they are sensitive to dry conditions. Cigars that are not stored properly can dry out, crack, or develop mold. If you have a cigar that you can't smoke right away, store it in an open ziplock bag with a slightly-moist towel at the mouth of the bag, placed in a dark space maintained at around 70 degrees Fahrenheit. Humidor bags, which are commonly sold at many cigar retailers, can keep cigars fresh for several weeks. At reputable cigar shops, the tobacconist will often ask how long you plan to keep the cigar and may pack it in a humidor bag. Don't hesitate to ask the tobacconist questions and seek their advice – they can provide valuable insights and guidance. Check the bag every few hours to make sure no dampness is accumulating inside. If dampness is accumulating, open the bag further and adjust the towel as needed. Cigars stored in a cedar cigar box in a cool, humid room will generally remain relatively fresh for an extended period, assuming the humidity levels are consistently maintained.

To measure an angle, hold the clinometer so the curved rim of the protractor faces downward. Tilt the clinometer until you see the top of a tall object, such as a building, through the straw or paper tube. You can use this method to measure the angle between you and the top of the object, or the object's height. Keep the clinometer steady until the string becomes still.

Calculate the angle between the midpoint of the protractor (90º) and the point where the string crosses the rim by subtracting one from the other. For example, if the string crosses at 60º, the angle of elevation is 30º (90-60). The angle will always be less than 90º since 90º is straight up.

If you subtract the larger number from the smaller and get a negative number, just remove the minus sign. For example, if you calculate 60-90=-30, the actual angle is +30º.

The tangent of an angle is the side opposite the angle, divided by the adjacent side. In this case, the side opposite is the object's height, and the adjacent side is the distance to the object.

To calculate the tangent, use a scientific or graphing calculator, an online calculator, or a tangent chart. If the answer is below 0 or above 1, set your calculator to degrees.

To find the object's height, you'll need to know the distance to its base. Measure using a tape measure, or count the steps and measure one step. The total distance is the length of one step multiplied by the number of steps.

Some protractors have rulers marked along the edge. The tangent of your angle is (object's height) / (distance between you and the object). Multiply the tangent by the distance, and you'll get the object's height.

For example, if the angle is 35º and your distance is 45 units, the object's height equals 31.5 units (45 x tangent(35º)). Add your own height to get the total height.

It represented my character, and together, we went through many memorable experiences in life. I had to make a tough and heartbreaking decision to sell it, but I did it for my wife and our two children. Their well-being and comfort are much more important to me than any sentimental object, including my beloved Corvette, but it still holds a special place in my heart. I told myself that when things turned around again, I could always get another one, but I knew that I would never replace the memories and experiences we shared. llama3.polished_text:
Here's the refined text:

Four months ago, I was forced to part with my most treasured possession, my faithful, yellow, 1971 Chevy Corvette, which had been a constant companion for many years. I had to sell it because I lost my job, and I had to take drastic measures to save our family home from foreclosure until things started to improve again.

I had been dreaming about this car since I was just seven years old, while browsing through car magazines with my school friends, and it had become an enduring obsession for me. One day, I came home from school and told my mom and dad that I was determined to own this car one day, and I could see the amusement in their faces as they tried to temper my naive childhood dreams with a more practical reality.

My parents were simple country folk, living in rural Texas, and they struggled to understand my fascination with fast cars and material possessions, which they saw as a frivolous waste of time and money. My father, a strict military man stationed at Fort Hood army base, was particularly dismissive of my desires, insisting that a man's primary duty was to serve his family and provide for their basic needs rather than indulging in luxuries.

However, I was a free spirit, with a strong sense of independence and a desire to forge my own path in life, which set me apart from my parents and their values. Despite their reservations, I pursued my dream of owning the Corvette, and I was able to purchase it with my own hard-earned money when I turned twenty-two.

Over the years, my car became more than just a prized possession; it was a symbol of my hard work and determination, a reflection of my character and values, and a trusted companion that had been with me through many memorable experiences and milestones. It was a reminder that I was capable of achieving my goals and realizing my dreams, no matter how challenging they may seem.

When I decided to sell the Corvette, it was a tough and heartbreaking decision, but I knew that I had to prioritize the well-being and comfort of my family above all else, even my beloved car. I told myself that I could always get another car in the future, but I knew that family happiness and stability were priceless and irreplaceable.

As I took the Corvette out of the garage for the last time and handed the keys to a young man from Salt Lake City, Utah, I couldn't help but feel a sense of sadness and nostalgia. However, when I looked into his eyes and saw the same excitement and enthusiasm that I had felt when I first got the car, I knew that I had made the right decision.

The young man reminded me of myself when I was younger, with a dream that had been achieved, and I wished him well and hoped that he would enjoy the Corvette as much as I had over the years. As I hugged my five-year-old son, who had been watching the scene unfold, he looked up at me with a big smile and said, "Dad, when I grow up, I will buy you the fastest car ever, and we will fly together!" That moment made all the pain and sadness worthwhile, and I knew that I had given my son a precious gift – the gift of hope and the knowledge that anything is possible with hard work and determination.

llama3.polished_text:
Here's the revised text with each sentence containing fewer than 32 tokens:

Humans selectively attend longer to the most relevant elements of a sentence (Rayner, 1998). 
This ability to evaluate importance is a key factor in human language understanding. 
Computational language models struggle to encode relative importance (Jain and Wallace, 2019). 
Alternative methods based on salience, vector normalization, or subset erasure are being developed (Bastings and Filippova, 2020; Kobayashi et al., 2020; De Cao et al., 2020). 
Human language processing can be approximated indirectly by tracking eye movements and fixation duration (Rayner, 1977). 
Fixation duration and relative importance of text segments are strongly correlated in natural reading (Malmaud et al., 2020). 
Being able to predict eye movement patterns from language input would bring us closer to understanding cognitive plausibility. 
Contextualized neural models are less interpretable but achieve high performance in many language understanding tasks (Merkx and Frank, 2020). 
Neural representations implicitly encode similar information as humans in cognitive signals (Wehbe et al., 2014; Abnar et al., 2019; Sood et al., 2020; Schrimpf et al., 2020). 
However, transformer models have not been analyzed for predicting human behavioral metrics such as gaze patterns. 
The performance of computational models can be improved using human cognitive signals (Hollenstein et al., 2019; Toneva and Wehbe, 2019; Takmaz et al., 2020). 
We focus on generating token-level predictions from natural reading, rather than specific phenomena (Hale, 2017). 
We fine-tune transformer models on human eye movement data and analyze their ability to predict reading behavior. 
We compare the performance of monolingual and multilingual transformer models on a range of reading features and languages. 
Multilingual models represent multiple languages in a joint space, aiming for a more universal language understanding. 
We test our hypothesis on 6 datasets of 4 Indo-European languages: English, German, Dutch, and Russian. 
Pretrained transformer models are surprisingly accurate at predicting reading time measures in four Indo-European languages. 
Multilingual models show an advantage over language-specific models, especially when fine-tuned on smaller amounts of data. 
Our results indicate that transformer models encode relative importance in a way comparable to human processing mechanisms. 
This suggests that neural models can be adjusted towards more cognitively plausible outputs without large-scale cognitive datasets.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Large-scale pre-training of language models has become the de facto standard approach for a wide range of natural language processing tasks, enabling models to acquire a robust understanding of linguistic structures and relationships. Furthermore, recent studies have demonstrated that models pre-trained on a massive amount of code can achieve competitive performance on various tasks, including code generation and code classification, which are essential for applications such as automated coding and code review. Our code and dataset are available at https://github.com/dashends/CodeSyntax, where researchers can access the benchmark and experiment with different models and configurations to evaluate their performance on code syntax understanding tasks. Figure 1 illustrates the syntactic relations between different tokens in natural languages and programming languages, highlighting the fundamental differences between these two domains and the challenges of understanding code syntax. The relations in programming languages represent the syntax of code in a way that is similar to those in natural languages, with each relation being represented by an arrow that connects the corresponding tokens. Figure 2 provides a preview of the model performance comparison on natural language and programming language syntax understanding tasks, showcasing the results of our evaluation on the CodeSyntax benchmark. Pre-trained models are generally able to capture natural language syntax relatively well, but they perform worse in understanding programming language syntax, which is a critical aspect of code representation learning. The Offset baseline picks the token using a fixed positional offset, which is a simple yet effective approach that can yield high accuracy in certain cases. We use BERT-large and RoBERTa-base configurations, which correspond to the configurations of CuBERT and CodeBERT, to evaluate the performance of pre-trained models on the CodeSyntax benchmark. The plot displays top-1 scores, which are an essential metric for evaluating the performance of models on code syntax understanding tasks. See Tables 3 and 4 for the full results of our evaluation, which provide a comprehensive overview of the performance of different models and configurations on the CodeSyntax benchmark. Code classification is a fundamental task in programming languages, where models need to identify the type of code and its corresponding syntax. These tasks are closely related to natural language tasks in their problem formulation, where models need to understand the syntax and semantics of language. Nowadays, the common practice for solving these coding tasks is to utilize the language model architectures and training schemes that are originally designed for natural language processing. The design principle of these neural language models is significantly different from the classic rule-based program generation systems, which were developed by pioneer PC contributors. Specifically, neural language models take the program as a token sequence, while classic program generation systems utilize the language grammar and code structure. Despite the advanced performance of pre-trained language models on code understanding tasks, what these models have learned from the code corpus remains unclear, and there is a need for further investigation into the effectiveness of pre-training for code representation learning. In this work, we investigate whether large-scale pre-training is all we need for code representation learning, and we introduce CodeSyntax, a large-scale benchmark consisting of programs annotated with the syntactic relationships between different tokens. The ground truth syntactic relationships are extracted from edges in the abstract syntax trees (AST) of the programs, which provide a structured representation of the code syntax. Figure 1 shows some examples of syntactic relationships between different tokens in programming languages, which are essential for understanding code syntax. These syntactic relations are function-wise similar to dependency relations for natural languages, where prior work has demonstrated that the attention heads of pre-trained language models can help to identify natural language relation types (Clark et al., 2019; Raganato et al., 2018). To measure how well the pre-trained language models capture the code syntactic structures, we adopt the approach to the PL domain, which involves evaluating the performance of models on a range of code syntax understanding tasks. We focus on investigating the zero-shot capability of existing pre-training methods in our experiments, and we evaluate these pre-trained models without fine-tuning them on our benchmark. We evaluate the state-of-the-art pre-trained language models for code representation learning, including CuBERT (Kanade et al., 2020) and CodeBERT (Feng et al., 2020), which are widely used for natural language processing tasks. A common characteristic of these models is that they share the same Transformer-based architectural design as natural language models (Vaswani et al., 2017; Devlin et al., 2019), which allows us to directly compare their performance in capturing the syntax structure. This allows us to directly compare their performance in capturing the syntax structure, which is a critical aspect of code representation learning. We present a preview of our key results in Figure 2, which showcase the performance of different models and configurations on the CodeSyntax benchmark. Our main observation is that pre-training is insufficient for learning the syntactic relations in code, and that directly applying training paradigms developed for natural language could be suboptimal for program learning. First, we find that the models pre-trained on code do not always outperform models pre-trained on natural language corpus alone, which suggests that pre-training on code may not be sufficient for learning code syntax. Surprisingly, compared to CodeBERT, which is trained on both text and code corpora, RoBERTa achieves better performance without training on any code with identical model architecture, which indicates that pre-training on programs as token sequences does not help learn the syntactic relations. This indicates that pre-training on programs does not help learn the syntactic relations, which is a critical aspect of code representation learning. On the contrary, without dependency relations, pre-training still enables language models to understand the natural language syntax to some extent, which suggests that pre-training can be beneficial for certain aspects of language understanding. Moreover, for code syntax understanding, the pre-trained models even perform worse than simple baselines that pick the tokens with a fixed offset, which is a simple yet effective approach that can yield high accuracy in certain cases. For example, always selecting the (p+2)-th token as the p-th token’s dependency yields higher accuracy than any attention head for several relation types. On the other hand, the same model architectures pre-trained on text corpora achieve decent accuracy in identifying the dependency relations in the natural language domain, where the performance of the same simple baselines is far behind. Our analysis reveals several key differences between natural language and programming languages that lead to different capabilities of understanding the syntax for pre-trained models, including the hierarchical structures of programs and the presence of tokens such as newlines and semicolons. First, programs are more structured than natural language sentences, with hierarchical structures representing long-term dependencies between code tokens. Programs usually contain hierarchical structures representing long-term dependencies between code tokens, which can be challenging for attention heads to recognize. Consequently, a large number of syntactic relation types are between distant tokens, which can be difficult to recognize for attention heads. On the contrary, the dependency relations in natural language sentences mostly connect nearby token pairs, and in this case the attention heads are more capable of identifying the correct relations. Meanwhile, language models are good at recognizing keyword-based relations, such as picking the corresponding else keyword for an if token, which is an essential aspect of code syntax understanding. Interestingly, we find that the inclusion of tokens such as newlines and semicolons notably affects the performance in the code domain, which is a critical aspect of code representation learning. Our findings suggest that existing pre-trained models perform quite differently in programming language and natural language domains in terms of the ability to understand syntax, which has significant implications for the design of language models. Thus, directly applying training paradigms developed for natural language could be suboptimal for program learning, and we consider designing better approaches to model the code structure as future work. CodeSyntax: Benchmarking Code Syntax Understanding We construct the CodeSyntax benchmark to evaluate the performance of language models on code syntax understanding, which is a critical aspect of code representation learning. We focus on Python and Java languages, on which the publicly released model checkpoints of both CuBERT (Kanade et al., 2020) and CodeBERT (Feng et al., 2020) are pre-trained, which allows us to directly compare the performance of these models on the CodeSyntax benchmark. We obtain the code samples from CodeSearchNet (Husain et al., 2019), which is a large-scale dataset consisting of code in different programming languages, which is essential for evaluating the performance of language models on code syntax understanding tasks.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Herbal products and the claims they make are not regulated by the FDA. In addition, companies making these claims are not required to provide evidence that supports them. There is some good preliminary evidence to support the possible benefits of some herbal products. Talk to your doctor before making any changes to your existing medication regimen, especially when it involves adding or changing herbal products. Herbal products can have side effects and interact with other medications. North American ginseng root has been rated as possibly effective in preventing colds by the United States National Library of Medicine. Taking 200mg of ginseng twice a day during the cold and flu season may help to prevent catching colds or possibly even the flu. This benefit may be effective for adults aged 18 to 65, according to the study. The researchers report that ginseng may not help to prevent the first cold of the season but may help to prevent further colds. Some evidence suggests that garlic may have the ability to help fight infections. Laboratory work has shown that garlic is effective against bacteria, fungi, and viruses like the flu and the common cold. While this work is promising, human research has yet to show that garlic is effective in controlled studies. There is clear research supporting the role of good bacteria in the gut in helping the immune system function properly. Probiotics do support good bacteria, but the direct link between taking probiotics and improving the immune system is still not established. When choosing probiotic products, select them carefully, as they are not regulated and not all are the same. Products containing herbs like aloe vera, echinacea, and licorice root claim to help prevent infections. Many of these agents can be harmful, and there is a lack of scientific evidence to support their claims of efficacy in improving immunity. This does not mean the claims are not true, but there is little evidence to support them. Echinacea has been extensively written about, claiming to help with the prevention of colds. Researchers suggest using echinacea with caution, as it may shorten the duration of a cold. Echinacea can be particularly hazardous for people with allergies to ragweed, who may suffer serious allergic reactions, including anaphylactic shock. There is little evidence that aloe vera has any significant impact on the immune response. Topical application of aloe vera has been shown to be helpful for various skin conditions, but there is no evidence to support its use in preventing colds. Licorice root has been used in Chinese medicine for many years, often in combination with other herbs and ingredients, but its specific claims of efficacy have not been scientifically validated. Talk to your doctor before using licorice root, as it can interact with many commonly used prescription medications. Do not use licorice root for an extended period of time due to potential risks.

The rapid development of Large Language Models (LLMs) has led to their widespread application in various domains, including dialogue systems and creative writings. Notably, research by Bae et al. (2022) and Swanson et al. (2021) have demonstrated the potential of LLMs in these areas, transcending their role as mere tools for daily convenience. Moreover, LLMs have become increasingly prevalent in various social-influencing domains, such as education (Kasneci et al., 2023; AlAfnan et al., 2023) and the technology industry (Dong et al., 2023), playing a more and more important role in social influence.

However, the existence of bias in LLMs is a pressing concern, particularly under such a context, as the social influence of LLMs can further promote the underlying legal and ethical implications (Weidinger et al., 2021; Deshpande et al., 2023). Many previous studies have identified gender bias in Natural Language Processing (NLP) models (Gupta et al., 2022; Sheng et al., 2019). For instance, research has shown that gender bias in LLMs can manifest in various tasks, such as language generation and text classification (Wan et al., 2023; Kotek et al., 2023).

Despite the significance of addressing gender bias in LLMs, previous works have often focused on specific tasks in the English context, using single-dimensional evaluation methods for gender bias (Wan et al., 2023; Kotek et al., 2023). However, LLMs generally receive different types of instructions for different utilizing circumstances, where the gender bias can be reflected in different aspects. Moreover, considering the diverse language backgrounds of LLM users and the strong capabilities in multilingual reasoning of the LLMs themselves (Lai et al., 2023; Bang et al., 2023; Rathje et al., 2023; Shi et al., 2023), it is essential to emphasize the various language features and cultural influences that affect how gender bias occurs in different languages.

Different languages may have different degrees of gender bias in LLM generations, and understanding this is crucial for acknowledging and mitigating these biases in LLMs, ensuring they are more equitable and culturally aware in the wide range of applications. To address the limitations of previous studies, our research emphasizes the substantial role of conversations undertaken by LLMs and explores gender bias in different dimensions. In particular, we present three quantitative evaluation measurements for gender bias in LLMs, which can reveal three-dimensional aspects of gender bias. These measurements are designed to provide a more comprehensive understanding of gender bias in LLMs, taking into account the nuances of language, culture, and context.

Based on the proposed measurements, we conduct experiments in six different languages using a range of state-of-the-art LLMs, such as GPT-3/4 (Brown et al., 2020). This allows us to compare the levels and nuances of gender bias across these languages, providing insights into the fact that diverse instructions may influence gender biases in LLM generations in different ways. Our approaches facilitate a comprehensive analysis of both lexicon and sentiment aspects of gender bias across different languages, enabling us to identify the specific language features and cultural influences that contribute to gender bias.

The main results of our exploration can be categorized into the following conclusions: Firstly, our findings suggest that LLMs exhibit varying degrees of gender bias in different languages, with some languages showing more significant bias than others. Secondly, our experiments demonstrate that the type of instructions used to train LLMs can significantly impact the level of gender bias in the generated text. Finally, our results highlight the importance of considering the cultural and linguistic context in which LLMs are used, as this can affect the way gender bias is perceived and addressed.

Overall, our research provides a more comprehensive understanding of gender bias in LLMs, highlighting the need for a nuanced and multi-faceted approach to addressing this issue. By emphasizing the role of conversations, language features, and cultural influences, our study contributes to the development of more equitable and culturally aware LLMs, which can be applied in a wide range of social-influencing domains.

llama3.polished_text:
When you find a baby bird on the ground, your instinct may be to take care of it. However, unless the bird is injured, you may cause more harm than good. 

Look for signs of injury or illness in baby birds: bleeding or open wounds; lifelessness; exhaustion or dehydration. If the bird seems calm or is moving around, it's likely not injured. If unsure, call a wildlife rehabilitator for guidance.

When handling the bird, wash your hands and/or wear gloves to prevent the transfer of bacteria or viruses. Hold the bird gently, using one thumb against its neck and your other fingers beneath and around it. If the bird is too big, use both thumbs and fingers on opposite sides.

Grip the bird tightly enough to keep it from falling or escaping, but don't squeeze it. Wash your hands thoroughly after handling the bird.

To create a temporary nest, use a cardboard shoebox with a soft base (e.g., a folded T-shirt or paper towels). Poke at least 12 holes in the lid. Ideally, have someone else prepare the box while you hold the bird, or create a nest box ahead of time.

Fashion about 12 tissues into a donut shape and place the bird in the center. Make sure the sides of the tissue nest aren't higher than the bird's head. If the bird can't sit squarely, try to position the tissues to prop it up.

Put a lid on the box to keep the nest dark, quiet, and cozy. If you have a heating pad, place it on its lowest setting and set the shoebox on top. If not, place the box in a warm, quiet spot.

Time is crucial – get the bird to a wildlife rehabilitator within 1-2 hours for the best chance of survival. Once in contact with a rehabilitator, put the shoebox in your car and drive to their location as soon as possible.

To find local wildlife rehabilitators, call your government's environmental department or check websites like https://ahnow.org/#/ and http://wildliferehabinfo.org/index.htm. Do not give the bird food or water unless directed to do so by the wildlife rehabilitator.

trips_llama3.polished_text: This year I decided that I wanted to start making a positive impact to help those less fortunate than me. Around Christmas time, I started to really notice how many people were struggling around me, which made a lasting impression. I knew it happened, but somehow I never really thought too much about it. About 2 weeks ago now, I was walking down the road on my way to get a cup of coffee before doing some Christmas shopping and I saw a bunch of businesses with people curled up outside them. They were trying to keep themselves warm with blankets, sleeping bags, and hats. Those were the lucky ones. I saw ones that were huddled up inside doorways, doing their best to stay warm and alive, with empty cups in front of them or signs begging for help. They were just begging people to help them with the basic needs that every human being needs and deserves. I don't know what it was that made me notice today, perhaps it was the stark contrast between my own excesses and their desperate struggles. Maybe because I was out spending too much money on Christmas presents that really weren't that needed when there are people who can't even afford a hot meal. I spotted one guy sitting there with just a small blanket, though he wasn't using it, it was curled around a small dog, who looked as though he had seen better days. I dug into my pockets and found that I had very little cash. I stopped to talk to him, and learned that he had been laid off two years ago and lost his home, with no family nearby. I talked to him for a bit, learning that he had found the dog abandoned one day and decided to keep him because he couldn't bear the thought of leaving him to fend for himself. His panhandling money went to feeding his dog, who was his best friend. I asked him if he was hungry and he looked at me quite surprised, saying he was starving and lucky to eat at all each day. He asked a friend of his a few feet away to watch his dog, and off we went to get some lunch together. I grabbed some sandwiches for the others I spotted and some hot cups of coffee, and of course, a bag of dog food for his buddy. We delivered the food, and I've never seen such unadulterated joy. It was a truly heartwarming moment, making a lot of people happy, but most of all, I made myself feel a sense of purpose and happiness that I hadn't felt in a long time.

When paddling a canoe, it's essential to understand the proper hand positioning to move efficiently and maintain control. Your inside hand is the one furthest from the side of the boat you're paddling on; your other hand should be positioned around 2-3 feet (0.6-0.9 meters) down from the top of the paddle. For instance, if you're paddling on the left side of the boat, your right hand would be your inside hand, which you would hold at the top of the paddle, while your left hand is positioned lower, approximately 2-3 feet down from the top. 

The goal is to bring the end of the paddle as far in front of you as possible without having to stand up from your seat, which will allow you to maintain a consistent and smooth pace. For example, if you're supposed to be paddling on the left side of the canoe, you would insert the paddle into the water in front of you to the left of the boat, ensuring the end of the paddle remains submerged in the water at all times.

To propel the canoe forward, you should push with your top hand and pull back with your bottom hand to move the paddle backward. Once the paddle is behind you and you can't go back any further, lift it out of the water and gently swing it back around in front of you to where you first put it in the water. This process should be repeated to move the canoe forward, keeping you on a straight course and preventing the canoe from going in circles. 

For synchronized paddling, it's crucial to maintain a harmonious rhythm, where both paddles enter and exit the water simultaneously. The bowman (at the front of the canoe) should set the pace, and the sternman should adjust their paddling to match them, creating a synchronized and efficient paddling motion.

A "J" stroke is a small backward stroke through the water, which can be used to steer the canoe. If you want the canoe to go left, the sternman should do a "J" stroke on the left side of the canoe; to go right, the sternman would do a "J" stroke on the right side of the canoe. The larger the backward stroke the sternman does, the more drastic of a turn the canoe will make.

On the other hand, a draw is when you extend a paddle out away from the boat, holding it vertically so just the flat end of the paddle is in the water. Then, you pull the paddle in toward the edge of the boat. If you ever need to make a sharp turn, both the bowman and sternman should do a draw on opposite sides of the canoe. To make a hard left turn, the sternman should draw on the right side of the canoe; to make a hard right turn, the sternman should draw on the left side of the canoe.

In the event of a capsize, it's essential to remain calm and act quickly to minimize any potential harm. If you tip over, tuck the paddles and any of your belongings under the seats in the flipped canoe. Holding on to the canoe, swim toward the nearest shore, taking care not to swim against a strong current if you're canoeing in a river. If you're far from shore, try flipping the canoe over with your partner, which can be made easier if both of you get under the flipped canoe and lift it up with your arms before attempting to flip it back over.

Medical abbreviation disambiguation has been extensively studied in previous work (Skreta et al., 2019; Li et al., 2019; Finley et al., 2016; Liu et al., 2018; Joopudi et al., 2018; Jin et al., 2019); this research serves as a foundation for our work, which expands and builds upon it. Our work differs from existing studies in two key ways. First, we propose using abbreviation disambiguation as a pre-training task for transfer learning on other clinical tasks, which can enhance model performance. Second, existing datasets for medical abbreviation disambiguation, such as CASI (Moon et al., 2014), are limited by their small size and high error rates compared to datasets used for general language model pre-training (Li et al., 2019). Therefore, we constructed a new, large-scale dataset to support effective pre-training and address the limitations of existing datasets. Our main contributions are: (1) presenting a large, publicly available dataset (MeDAL) for pre-training on medical abbreviation disambiguation, and (2) providing empirical evidence of the benefits of abbreviation pre-training for various deep learning architectures, with potential applications in the medical domain.
